title: Three generations of Oldhams pushing 70 years at Musicians' Repair and Sales
text:
Three generations of Oldhams pushing 70 years at Musicians' Repair and Sales Jenna Watson , jenna.watson@indystar.com Published 8:00 p.m. ET Feb. 5, 2017 | Updated 22 hours ago CLOSE x Share Look and listen inside Musicians' Repair and Sales in downtown Indianapolis, pushing its 70th year in business. Three father-son generations of Oldhams, Maury, 90, Rick, 58, and Dan, 31, keep the shop's purpose alive. Jenna Watson/IndyStar Buy Photo Maury Oldham, the founding owner at Musicians' Repair and Sales, tinkers with a bassoon that is mid-repair, Indianapolis, Wednesday, Jan. 11, 2017. Oldham opened shop in 1948 and still works several days a week to offer advice and expertise. Maury's son and grandson Rick and Dan own and oversee the shop day to day. (Photo: Jenna Watson/IndyStar) Buy Photo 
At his cramped studio space at Pennsylvania and New York streets Downtown, Maury Oldham kept milk and bologna out on the window ledge in the cold months. He used the public restroom in the hall to freshen up. On weekends, he made trips to do laundry at his parents' house in Rush County. 
For a few years before he married in 1950, his workspace doubled as a place to live. 
That rental unit was the humble beginning of Musicians’ Repair and Sales, now located at 322 N. Capitol Ave., in a freestanding white brick building. On the shop’s south-facing exterior, a black-and-white mural depicts the eight “Jazz Masters of Indiana Avenue.” 
Through high school, Oldham’s 10-piece big band brought proms and community dances to life. Upon graduation, Oldham took his love of music to Butler University. Despite investing two years at the School of Music, his future as a full-time musician was uncertain. An aptitude test ranked Oldham competent in music, art and mechanics. With that in mind, he took a leap of faith to learn to fix instruments at the C.G. Conn repair school in Elkhart. Musicians Repair Service, Inc., as it was called then, was born in Indianapolis in 1948. 
Now 90 years old, Maury, a “master craftsman,” still works in the shop twice a week. Rick Oldham, 58, one of Maury’s five children, is the second-generation owner. 
“I’ve been working here since I was 12," Rick said. "We all worked here at some point. I’m the one who stuck with it. Dan was coming in when he was in elementary school.” 
Rick’s son Dan Oldham, 31, is the third generation of Oldhams keeping the tradition alive. Dan is a liaison to outside clients looking to rent, buy or repair instruments. 
The business works with music programs from the elementary level all the way up to Indiana University’s Marching Hundred. Choir risers, printed sheet music, boxes of reeds, you name it. The shop markets far beyond repairs. Buy Photo 
Michael Gonser, a repairman at Musicians' Repair and Sales, works on a flute, Indianapolis, Wednesday, Jan. 11, 2017. (Photo: Jenna Watson/IndyStar) 
However, decades of authentic craftsmanship is what makes the shop stand out. 
“When I was a kid and there were still big bands that would travel in the ‘70s, the busses of guys would just stop out in front of the store and they would all come in,” Rick said. “They rarely saw a ‘real’ instrument store that dealt with acoustic instruments like we do.” 
In some ways, that hasn’t changed. Maury recalled when Woody Herman and his band stopped on their way from Chicago to Louisville in the ‘50s. His grandson Dan more recently remembered when Jeff Coffin of the Dave Matthews Band came by for a repair. 
“We see the guys in the band. We don’t see the stars, unless the star is a jazz guy,” Rick said. 
The shop runs on one particular objective: To see that people play and continue to make music. 
“Whether that’s a beginner that’s never played and you’ve given them a chance to make their first sound, or whether it’s a guy that’s playing in a smoky jazz club tonight, or a guy that’s playing on a major stage with a major name, it’s all about supporting those people that continue to make music,” Rick said he reminds his staff. “A student in junior high needs an instrument to play just as well as the person that’s playing at the Jazz Kitchen tonight.” 
Many of the shop’s dozen employees learned through mentorship. It takes one to two years of apprenticeship to become familiar with your area of focus, and six to 10 years to be able to fix “just about anything,” according to Rick. Buy Photo 
An array of tiny tools and gadgets for repairing instruments are gritty from years of use, seen sitting at one of several workstations at Musicians' Repair and Sales, Indianapolis, Wednesday, Jan. 11, 2017. (Photo: Jenna Watson/IndyStar) 
Every repair is a unique task, ranging from removing a dent from a sousaphone to refurbishing a dilapidated antique harp. 
“There’s a lot of mechanical ingenuity between all of the guys and girls who work here, so if something is odd, they can discuss it,” Rick said. 
Technicians typically specialize in a department — woodwinds, brass or strings — and most enjoy playing just as much as repairing. 
The Oldhams credit their success to decades of consistent, high-quality products and services. Maury recalled one customer who found a note in his dressing room after a show in Ohio or Pennsylvania. It read, “If you need some good saxophone repair done, see Maury at Musician’s Repair in Indianapolis.” 
“Often I hear from people, ‘Oh, I came in here when I was a kid,’ or ‘My grandpa used to bring me in here because he always came here.’” Rick said. “We hear that a lot because we’ve been around for almost 70 years.” 422 CONNECT COMMENT EMAIL MORE Read or Share this story: http://indy.st/2kDBs23 TOP VIDEOS
